section.title: Area and Arc Length in Polar Coordinates

li.p: How can we compute the area of a sector bounded by a curve?
How can we find the area between two curves?
How can we compute slope and arc length in polar coordinates?

introduction.p: Any point P = (x,y) on the Cartesian plane can be represented in polar coordinates using its distance from the origin point (0,0) and the angle formed from the positive x-axis counterclockwise to the point. Sometimes this representation provides a more useful way of describing the point's location, or even all of the points along a curve, than conventional Cartesian coordinates.

Representing curves in polar coordinates, we can continue to ask the same questions such as What is the area under the curve? and How long is the curve? . In this section we learn how the definite integral may be used to find answers to these questions.

subsection.title: A Review of Polar Coordinates

assemblage.title: Polar Coordinates
assemblage.p: The polar coordinatespolar coordinates of a point consist of an ordered pair, (r,\theta), where r is the distance from the point to the origin and \theta is the angle measured in standard position.

To convert between polar coordinates and Cartesian coordinates, we can use known trigonometric relationships.

assemblage.p: To convert between polar (r,\theta)- and Cartesian (x,y)-coordinates, we can use the following relationships

subsection.p: From these relationships and our knowledge of the unit circle, if r=1 and \theta=\pi/3, the polar coordinates would be (r,\theta)=\left(1,\frac{\pi}{3}\right) and the corresponding Cartesian coordinates would be (x,y)=\left(\frac{1}{2},\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right)

note.p: Remembering your unit circle values will come in very handy as you convert between Cartesian and polar coordinates.

statement.p: Find the Cartesian coordinates of a point with the polar coordinates (r,\theta)=\left(5,\frac{2\pi}{3}\right).

solution.p:
Using the above relationships, the x- and y-coordinates of the point are
x \amp= r\cos(\theta) = 5\cos\left(\frac{2\pi}{3}\right)=5\left(-\frac{1}{2}\right)=-\frac{5}{2},
y \amp= r\sin(\theta) = 5\sin\left(\frac{2\pi}{3}\right)=5\left(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right)=\frac{5\sqrt{3}}{2}.
Note that since 2\pi/3 is a common angle on the unit circle, we can find the exact Cartesian coordinates rather than using a calculator to find approximate values for x and y.

statement.p: Find the Cartesian coordinates of a point with the polar coordinates (r, \theta)=(2, \, 4.3).

solution.p:
Using the above relationships, the x- and y-coordinates of the point are x=r\cos(\theta)=2\cos(4.3) \hspace{.25in} \text{ and } \hspace{.25in} y=r\sin(\theta)=2\sin(4.3). Since \theta=4.3 radians is not a common angle on the unit circle, we need to use our calculators to find approximate values for x and y. Doing so, we get
x \amp= 2\cos(4.3) \approx -0.8016,
y \amp= 2\sin(4.3) \approx -1.8323.

statement.p: Find the polar coordinates of a point with the Cartesian coordinates (x,y)=(3,-4).

solution.p: Let's start by plotting the point (x,y)=(3,-4) on a graph and using the Pythagorean theorem to find the corresponding radius of the point. We get that

Now that we know the radius, we can find the angle using any of the three trigonometric relationships. Keep in mind that there may be more than one solution when solving for \theta and we will need to consider the quadrant that our (x,y) point is in to decide which solution to use.

Using the cosine function, we get that \cos(\theta) = \frac{x}{r} = \frac{3}{5} = 0.6 . Since this cosine value does not correspond to a common angle on the unit circle, we must use the inverse cosine function to solve for \theta, which gives us \theta = \cos^{-1}(0.6) \approx 0.927 \text{ radians}.

Since 0.927 is greater than 0 and less than \pi/2 \approx 1.571, we know that \theta=0.927 lies in Quadrant I. Since the point (x,y)=(3,-4) is located in Quadrant IV, we must find the other angle on the unit circle with \cos(\theta) = 0.6.

image.description: unit circle with cos(\theta)=0.6 one angle shown and labeled

solution.p: We can use the symmetry of the unit circle to find this second angle. By symmetry, the magnitudes of the two angles shown below are equal. Thus, \theta=-0.927 is another angle that satisfies \cos(\theta) = 0.6.

image.description: unit circle with cos(\theta)=0.6 two angles shown and labeled

solution.p: Therefore, the polar coordinates of the point are (r,\theta)=(5, -0.927).

statement.p: Find the polar coordinates of a point with the Cartesian coordinates (x,y)=\left(-4\sqrt{2},4\sqrt{2}\right).

solution.p: Let's start by plotting the point (x,y)=\big(-4\sqrt{2},4\sqrt{2}\big) on a graph and using the Pythagorean theorem to find the corresponding radius of the point. We get that

sidebyside.p:
r^2 \amp= x^2 + y^2
r^2 \amp= \big(-4\sqrt{2}\big)^2 + \big(4\sqrt{2}\big)^2
r^2 \amp= 32 + 32
r^2 \amp= 64
r \amp= 8 .

solution.p: Now that we know the radius, we can find the angle using any of the three trigonometric relationships. Keep in mind that there may be more than one solution when solving for \theta and we will need to consider the quadrant that our (x,y) point is in to decide which solution to use.
Using the sine function, we get that \sin(\theta) = \frac{y}{r} = \frac{4\sqrt{2}}{8}=\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}.

Since y=\sqrt{2}/2 corresponds to a common angle on the unit circle, we can find an exact value for \theta. The two angles that have a sine value of \sqrt{2}/2 on the unit circle are \theta=\frac{\pi}{4} \hspace{.25in} \text{ and } \hspace{.25in} \theta=\frac{3\pi}{4}.
Since the point (x,y)=\big(-4\sqrt{2},4\sqrt{2}\big) is located in Quadrant II, we can determine that \theta=3\pi/4. Thus, the polar coordinates are (r,\theta)=\left(8, \frac{3\pi}{4}\right).

subsection.title: Examples of Graphs in Polar Coordinates
subsection.p: Any equation written in Cartesian coordinates can be converted to one in polar coordinates and vice-versa. In practice, it makes sense to use the representation that is most natural for the application, or the one which is simpler to express. For example, the unit circle of radius 1 about the origin may be expressed in Cartesian coordinates using the equation x^2 + y^2 = 1. Since the points on the circle are precisely those points at distance r from the origin, in polar coordinates the equation may be written as r = 1.

Algebraically, we can see that this is correct by substituting x = r \cos(\theta) and y = r \sin(\theta) into the original equation to obtain x^2 + y^2 = 1 r^2 \cos^2(\theta) + r^2 \sin^2(\theta) = 1 r^2\big( \cos^2(\theta) + \sin^2(\theta) \big) = 1 . Using the trig identity \cos^2(\theta) + \sin^2(\theta) =1 , this becomes r^2 = 1 . Since r denotes the length of the radius to the point, it follows that r\gt0; hence, r = 1.
We now look at some special families of graphs in polar coordinates.

statement.p: One interesting family of graphs in polar coordinates are the rose graphs . These are curves of the form r = a \cos (n \theta) or r = a \sin (n \theta), where n is a positive integer and a \gt 0 .

figure.caption: Three rose graphs, r=\sin(3\theta), r=\sin(4\theta), and r=\sin(5\theta).

statement.p: Now go to this Desmos link and make more roses. What changes as you change the value of a? The value of n?

solution.p: The size of the rose increases directly with a. The value of n changes the number of petals. In particular, if n is odd, there will be n petals, and if n is even, there will be 2n petals.

statement.p: Another noteworthy graph is the Archimedean spiral . This curve has the equation r = \theta and is shown below. The general class of spirals is given by the expression r = a + b\theta where a \gt 0 .

figure.caption: Three Archimedean spirals, r=\theta, r=2\theta+1, and r=0.4 \theta+3.

statement.p: Now go to this Desmos link and make more spirals. What changes as you change the value of b? The value of a?

solution.p: The value of b controls how tight the spiral is. The value of a controls the initial radius of the spiral, namely the value of r when \theta=0.

section.subsection:
Calculating Area using Polar Coordinates
First consider a circle of radius r as shown in the image below.
To find the area of a sector with angle \theta, we calculate the fraction of the area of the sector compared to the area of the circle. Thus, \text{Area of Sector} = \frac{\theta}{2\pi} (\pi r^2) = \frac{1}{2}r^2 \theta .
To find regions of more general shapes, we will consider slicing them into thin regions and approximating the areas of those regions with sectors.
Consider the function f(\theta)=\cos(2\theta) and the region given by the graph of r=f(\theta) on the interval 0 \leq \theta \leq 2 \pi (shown below).
How would we approximate the area of this region? Our normal strategy would be to cut the region into rectangles and take a Riemann sum of the areas of those rectangles, but because we are working in polar coordinates, it is more natural to approximate the region with the sectors of a circle. One such sector is drawn on the image. That sector has an angle of \Delta \theta and a radius of f(\theta_i), so
\text{area}_{\text{slice}} \approx \text{area}_{\text{sector}}= \frac 12 (f(\theta_i))^2 \Delta \theta .
Taking the Riemann sum and taking the limit as \Delta \theta \rightarrow 0 , we get that the area of the region is given by the integral \int_\alpha^\beta \frac 12 (f(\theta))^2 \, d \theta .
For this particular function, the area contained by r=f(\theta) on the interval 0\le\theta\le2\pi is thus \int^{2\pi}_0\frac12\cos^2(2\theta)\,d\theta=\frac{\pi}2.
We summarize our finding here:
polar coordinatesarea Area in Polar Coordinates
For a curve r = f(\theta) where f(\theta) \ge 0 , the area between the origin and the curve f(\theta) from \alpha to \beta is \text{Area} = \frac{1}{2} \int_{\theta=\alpha}^{\theta=\beta} f(\theta)^2 \ d\theta .
Consider the Archimedean spiral given by r=\theta. Find the area traced out in the first loop of the spiral (from \theta=0 to \theta=2\pi).
Apply the formula in Area in Polar Coordinates.
A=\frac{4}{3} \pi^3 .
Since r=f(\theta)=\theta, then by the "Area in Polar Coordinates" formula,
A\amp= \frac 12 \int_{\theta=0}^{\theta=2\pi}\theta^2 \, d \theta \amp=\left. \frac 16 \theta^3 \right |_{\theta=0}^{\theta=2\pi} \amp= \frac{4}{3} \pi^3 .
Consider the rose given by r=\sin(4\theta). Find the area traced out by the rose (the entire rose is traced out from \theta=0 to \theta=2\pi).
Apply the formula in Area in Polar Coordinates and the trig identity \sin^2(x)=\frac 1 2 - \frac 1 2 \cos(2x).
A= \frac \pi 2 .
Since r=f(\theta)=\sin(4\theta), then by the "Area in Polar Coordinates" formula,
A\amp= \frac 12 \int_{\theta=0}^{\theta=2\pi}\big(\sin(4\theta)\big)^2 \, d \theta \amp= \frac 12 \int_{\theta=0}^{\theta=2\pi}\left(\frac 1 2 -\frac 1 2\cos (8 \theta)\right) \, d \theta \amp=\left. \frac 12 \left(\frac 1 2\theta - \frac 1 {16} \sin(8 \theta)\right) \right |_{\theta=0}^{\theta=2\pi} \amp= \frac \pi 2 .

This region goes from \theta=0 to \theta= \frac \pi 2, so its area is given by
A\amp= \frac 1 2 \int_0^{\frac \pi 2} (f(\theta))^2 \, d \theta \amp= \frac 1 2 \int_0^{\frac \pi 2} \theta^2 \, d \theta \amp= \left. \frac 1 6 \theta^3 \right|_0^{\frac \pi 2} \amp=\frac{\pi^3}{48} .

subsection.title: Slope and Arc Length with Polar Coordinates
subsection.p: We can think of a curve r = f(\theta) in terms of x and y by using x = r \cos(\theta) and y = r\sin(\theta) . In this way, the curve may be seen as being parametrized by \theta . Thus, we may use the formulas for slope and arc length of parametric equations to obtain formulas for slope and arc length in polar coordinates.

assemblage.title: Slope in Polar Coordinates
assemblage.p: The slope of a curve r = f(\theta) is \frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{\big(\frac{dy}{d\theta}\big)}{\big(\frac{dx}{d\theta}\big)} .

assemblage.title: Arc Length in Polar Coordinates
assemblage.p: The arc length of the curve r = f(\theta) , where x = r \cos(\theta) and y = r\sin(\theta) , is \text{Arc Length} = \int_{\theta=\alpha}^{\theta=\beta} \sqrt{\left(\frac{dx}{d \theta} \right)^2 + \left(\frac{dy}{d \theta}\right)^2 } \, d\theta.

statement.p:
Let f(\theta)=2\theta+3, and consider the Archimedean spiral given by the equation r=f(\theta) for 0 \leq \theta \leq 2 \pi. The spiral is shown below.
The point labelled "A" is at \theta=3 \pi/4. Find the (x,y)-coordinates of A and the slope of the tangent line there.
The point labelled "B" is at \theta=7 \pi/4. Find the (x,y)-coordinates of B and the slope of the tangent line there.
Find the length of the piece of the spiral in the third quadrant. (You may wish to use a computer or calculator to numerically evaluate the integral.)

li.p: You will need to evaluate \frac{dx}{d\theta} and \frac{dy}{d\theta} at A.
You will need to evaluate \frac{dx}{d\theta} and \frac{dy}{d\theta} at B.
Find \frac{dx}{d\theta} and \frac{dy}{d\theta} and use the arc length formula in "Arc Length in Polar Coordinates".

Since r=2 \theta+3, x=r \cos(\theta), and y=r \sin(\theta), and \theta=\frac{3\pi}4 at A, then r=\frac{3 \pi}{2}+3,\\ x= \left(\frac{3 \pi}{2}+3 \right)\left(-\frac{\sqrt 2}2\right) \approx -5.45, \text{ and}\\ y= \left(\frac{3 \pi}{2}+3 \right)\left(\frac{\sqrt 2}2\right) \approx 5.45 .
Now to find \frac{dy}{dx} we write
x= r \cos(\theta)=(2 \theta+3) \cos(\theta)\\ y= r \sin(\theta)=(2 \theta+3) \sin(\theta).
Thus, taking \frac{d}{d\theta}[x] and \frac{d}{d\theta}[y] and applying the product rule, we get
\frac{dx}{d\theta} = 2\cos(\theta)+ (2 \theta +3)(-\sin(\theta))\\ \frac{dy}{d\theta} = 2\sin(\theta)+ (2 \theta +3)(\cos(\theta)) .
Finally, plugging in \theta= \frac{3 \pi}{4} gives
\frac{dy}{dx}= \frac{\left(\frac{dy}{d\theta}\right)}{\left(\frac{dx}{d\theta}\right)} \amp= \frac{2\sin(\theta)+ (2 \theta +3)(\cos(\theta))}{2\cos(\theta)+ (2 \theta +3)(-\sin(\theta))} \amp\approx 0.588 .

Since r=2 \theta+3, x=r \cos(\theta), and y=r \sin(\theta), and \theta=\frac{7\pi}4 at B, then r=\frac{7 \pi}{2}+3,\\ x= \left(\frac{7 \pi}{2}+3 \right)(\frac{\sqrt 2}2) \approx 9.89, \text{ and}\\ y= \left(\frac{7 \pi}{2}+3 \right)(-\frac{\sqrt 2}2) \approx -9.89 .
We note that \frac{dy}{dx}=\frac{2\sin(\theta)+ (2 \theta +3)(\cos(\theta))}{2\cos(\theta)+ (2 \theta +3)(-\sin(\theta))}, as in part (a). Thus, plugging in \theta=\frac{7\pi}4 gives \frac{dy}{dx}\approx0.7499.

Note that the third quadrant is from \theta= \pi to \theta= \frac{3\pi}2. Using our computations from part (a), we know that
\frac{dx}{d\theta} = 2\cos(\theta)+ (2 \theta +3)(-\sin(\theta))\\ \frac{dy}{d\theta} = 2\sin(\theta)+ (2 \theta +3)(\cos(\theta)) .
Now, plugging into the arc length formula for a parametric equation, we get that
\text{Arc Length} = \int_\pi^{\frac{3\pi}{2}} \sqrt{ \left( \frac{dx}{d\theta}\right)^2+\left( \frac{dx}{d\theta}\right)^2} d \theta \\ = \int_\pi^{\frac{3\pi}{2}} \sqrt{ \left( 2\cos(\theta)+ (2 \theta +3)(-\sin(\theta))\right)^2+\left( 2\sin(\theta)+ (2 \theta +3)(\cos(\theta))\right)^2} d \theta \\ \approx 17.33
.

To find the area of a region bounded by a polar curve, we think of the region as being sliced up into thin circle sectors. The exact area of the region bounded by r=f(\theta) between \theta=\alpha and \theta=\beta is
\text{Area}= \frac 12 \int_{\theta=\alpha}^{\theta=\beta} (f(\theta))^2 \, d \theta.

To find the area of a region bounded by two polar curves, we subtract the smaller area from the larger one. If the two curves are r=f(\theta) and r=g(\theta), where f(\theta)\geq g(\theta), between \theta=\alpha and \theta=\beta, then the exact area is
\text{Area}= \frac 12 \int_{\theta=\alpha}^{\theta=\beta} (f(\theta))^2 \, d \theta-\frac 12 \int_{\theta=\alpha}^{\theta=\beta} (g(\theta))^2 \, d \theta = \frac 12 \int_{\theta=\alpha}^{\theta=\beta} (f(\theta))^2-(g(\theta))^2 \, d \theta .

To compute slope and arc length of a curve in polar coordinates, we treat the curve as a parametric function of \theta and use the parametric slope and arc length formulae:
\frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{\big(\frac{dy}{d\theta}\big)}{\big(\frac{dx}{d\theta}\big)} ,
\text{Arc Length} = \int_{\theta=\alpha}^{\theta=\beta} \sqrt{\left(\frac{dx}{d \theta} \right)^2 + \left(\frac{dy}{d \theta}\right)^2 } \, d\theta .
